revision.text:
{{for|the arena located in Karlskrona|Telenor Arena Karlskrona}} {{other uses|Telenor (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{good article}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Telenor Arena | nickname = Gymsalen,{{cite news|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2010/03/21/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/stabek/10946371/|title=– Det var ikke ett rop om "gymsal"|last=Kvamme|first=Sigve|date=21 March 2010|work=Dagbladet.no|language=Norwegian|accessdate=26 July 2011}} Hangar'n | image = [[File:Telenor Arena Eurovision 2010.JPG|300px]] | location = [[Fornebu]], [[Bærum]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{coord|59.9037|10.623|type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = 2007 | opened = 8 March 2009 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Euforum Holding]] | operator = Fornebu Arena AS | surface = Asphalt | construction_cost = [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 585 million
[[Euro|EUR €]] 65 million | architect = HRTB | main_contractors = [[NCC AB|NCC]] | former_names = | nicknames = | tenants = [[Stabæk Fotball]] (2009–2011)
[[F.C.Y. Rosenborg Trondheim|Rosenborg]] (2015-Present) | seating_capacity = 15,000 (sport)
23,000 (concerts) | record_attendance = 26,000{{Citation needed|date=December 2012}} | dimensions = }} '''Telenor Arena''', sometimes referred to as '''Fornebu Arena''', is a multi-purpose indoor [[arena]] located at [[Fornebu]] in [[Bærum]], outside [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. It serves as a venue for a variety of events, including concerts, exhibitions, action shows, family shows, TV and sport. It has a capacity for 15,000 spectators for sports and 23,000 for concerts, including 40 [[luxury boxes]] and [[club seating]] for 1,200. The venue has a fixed roof and an asphalt floor. The venue was opened ahead of the [[2009 Tippeligaen|2009]] Norwegian [[Association football|football]] season as a replacement for [[Nadderud Stadion]]. It cost 585 million [[Norwegian krone]]r (NOK) to build, of which NOK 300 million was for the sports venue. During the 2000s, Nadderud was below standards for play in the top national league. Fornebu was at the time undergoing an [[urban redevelopment]]; after several years of negotiations and public grants, Stabæk secured a lot in 2004. Construction started in 2007. In 2010, a disagreement arose between the club and venue-owner [[Kjell Chr. Ulrichsen]], with the latter demanding that the team leave the venue to allow for more event revenue. Telenor Arena has hosted the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]], as well as concerts by artists and bands of international fame, such as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Tina Turner]], [[Adele]], [[Muse (band)|Muse]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Roger Waters]] (the Wall tour), [[Rihanna]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Beyoncé]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Kanye West]], [[Metallica]], [[AC/DC]], [[Black Sabbath]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Justin Bieber]] and [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]. [[Telenor]] holds the [[naming rights]]. ==History== ===Planning=== Stabæk traditionally has played their home games at [[Nadderud Stadion]], a municipal [[multi-purpose stadium]] at [[Bekkestua]]. Following the club's rapid ascent from lower divisions to the top league during the first half of the 1990s, Nadderud became in need of upgrades, resulting in a new main grandstand opening in 1996.{{cite news |title=Nadderud stadion in "new look" |last=Nesbø |first=Knut |authorlink=Knut Nesbø |date=14 February 1996 |work=[[Aftenposten]] |page=15 |language=Norwegian}} The stadium remained severely lacking adequate facilities for professional football, and fell short of increasing requirements from the [[Football Association of Norway]] (NFF).{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/sport/stab-k/reservearena-er-utelukket-for-stabek-1.5871251 |title=Reservearena er utelukket for Stabæk |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Lars |date=8 December 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBf2Tapj?url=http://www.budstikka.no/sport/stab-k/reservearena-er-utelukket-for-stabek-1.5871251 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Originally, a redevelopment of Nadderud was proposed, but in 1999 Stabæk players launched the idea of building a new stadium at Fornebu, which became subject to an [[urban redevelopment]] project after the 1998 closing of [[Oslo Airport, Fornebu]]. The initial proposal was named Blue Dream Arena, would have seating for 25,000 spectators, blue artificial turf and a [[retractable roof]].Jensen, 2008: 13 Other proposed amenities were [[movable seating]] which would also allow the stadium to both host [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] and be configured as an intimate football stadium.{{cite news |title=Fornebu blir hjemmearena fra 2004 |last=Sandven |first=Arild |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=11 May 2001 |page=41 |language=Norwegian}} The idea called for [[Bruce Springsteen]] to hold a concert before the first match, which would be played against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. Several of the initial concepts of the stadium were never materialized. International rules disallowed blue artificial turf; instead, the flooring in the boxes were made in a blue, artificial turf-inspired material. Also the idea of having a retractable roof was discarded, both because of technical difficulties and cost issues.Jensen, 2008: 258–59 [[File:Fornebu (luft).jpg|thumb|Aerial view of [[Fornebu]] with Telenor Arena to the right]] In May 2001, Oslo City Council voted to sell their properties at Fornebu to Fornebu Boligspar (FB), which again had agreements to sell a lot for the stadium to Stabæk. In November 2002, [[Borgarting Court of Appeal]] concluded that [[Norrønafly]] had the right to continue leasing a hangar—located at the planned location of the venue—until 2014.{{cite news |title=Hangar stopper Stabæks stadion |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=17 November 2002 |page=47 |language=Norwegian}} In June 2003, Stabæk was in financial difficulties, and investor [[Kjell Chr. Ulrichsen]] bought shares for NOK 10 million to avoid bankruptcy; these shares had the [[option (law)|option]] to be converted to shares in the arena company.{{cite news |title=Stabæk har også en rik onkel Legger 10 millioner i nytt Stabæk-stadion |last=Skomakerstuen |first=Bjørn |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=25 June 2003 |page=14 |language=Norwegian}} Fornebu Boligspar later determined that it was more profitable to build apartments at the arena site. Negotiations started between the club, the property company and Mayor [[Odd Reinsfelt]]. In November 2003, it was announced that a compromise was reached whereby Fornebu Boligspar would give the lot free to Stabæk, in exchange for a lot nearby.{{cite news |title=Ordfører Odd Reinsfelt fant løsningen for Stabæk og Fornebu Boligspar |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=27 November 2003 |page=26 |language=Norwegian}} Two weeks later the compromise was rejected by FB.{{cite news |title=Ingen enighet om Fornebu Arena |last=Fredagsvik |first=Jarle |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=11 December 2003 |page=28 |language=Norwegian}} A new compromise was announced on 29 June 2004, whereby FB would give 50 million [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK) and a lot free to Stabæk in exchange for the commercial properties which would be part of the stadium.{{cite news |title=Enige om stadionløsning på Fornebu |agency=[[Aftenposten]] |date=29 June 2004 |language=Norwegian}} However, the following day the parties announced that they were not able to agree on the risk, as Stabæk demanded that FB take the full risk in the project.{{cite news |title=Bråstopp for Stabæk på Fornebu |last=Bugge |first=Mette |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=30 June 2004 |page=21 |language=Norwegian}} Instead, Stabæk started negotiating with [[IT Fornebu]] to take over a lot they owned. They needed a {{convert|300|ha}} lot which would have a market value of between NOK 60 and 80 million, and Reinsfelt stated that the municipality was willing to help by "maneuver in gray areas within the margins".{{cite news |title=Nytt håp for Stabæk på Fornebu |last=Thoresen |first=Thore-Erik |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=2 July 2004 |page=32 |language=Norwegian}} The club was further pressured by NFF, who were going to limit the exceptions allowed for Nadderud and other stadiums not meeting their criteria. On 29 October, FB and Stabæk signed an agreement whereby Stabæk received a free lot and NOK 50 million, in exchange for FB taking over the commercial properties. The condition was that the municipality allowed a more dense use of the rest of FB's area. This would require a re-regulation of the area, and Reinsfelt estimated that it would not be possible for construction to start until 2006.{{cite news |title=Stabæk vant – får drømmearenaen |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=30 October 2004 |page=18 |language=Norwegian}} In November, UEFA changed the rules for artificial turf to state that it had to be green. Until Stabæk's proposal was made, UEFA had not thought that anyone would build a pitch with a non-green turf, and representatives stated that it was because of Stabæk the rule change was made.{{cite news |title=Nei til blått |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |date=10 November 2004 |page=32 |language=Norwegian}} The plans were nearly terminated in October 2006, after discussion about the planned [[Fornebu Line]]—a [[people mover]] which would connect Fornebu to [[Lysaker]]—stopped the regulation plan.{{cite news |title=Foreløpig stopp for Stabæks stadion |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=18 October 2006 |page=48 |language=Norwegian}} However, in November the final permissions were granted by Bærum Municipality.{{cite news |title=Stabæk fikk ja til nytt stadion |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=9 November 2006 |page=48 |language=Norwegian}} On 22 December, Stabæk announced that the financing was secured.{{cite news |title=Stabæk- bygg til 550 mill.|last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=23 December 2006 |page=23 |language=Norwegian}} [[File:Fornebu arena innvendig.jpg|thumb|left|During construction]] ===Construction=== Architects were HRTB{{cite web |url=http://www.hrtb.no/prosjekter/ku_lo_fornebu.html |title=Telenor Arena |publisher=HRTB |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yDR0YrlD?url=http://www.hrtb.no/prosjekter/ku_lo_fornebu.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} and the main contractor was [[NCC Construction]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ncc.no/no/Konsepter/Listpage/Bygg-og-Anlegg/telenor-arena/ |title=Telenor Arena |publisher=[[NCC Construction]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yCoseyrC?url=http://www.ncc.no/no/Konsepter/Listpage/Bygg-og-Anlegg/telenor-arena/ |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} While [[dome]]d stadiums have been common in North America, no such stadiums of comparable size of Telenor Arena had previously been built for football in Europe.{{cite news |title=– Fotball blir innendørsidrett NFF-sjef tror på kunstgress og tak |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=2 December 2005 |page=28 |language=Norwegian}} Construction started by demolishing a hangar, which was completed in February 2007. However, because of the building boom, concrete elements needed for construction to start meant that the rest of the construction was delayed. The cornerstone was laid on 5 September.{{cite news |title=Motto for Fornebu Arena |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=6 September 2007 |page=48 |language=Norwegian}} [[File:Superfinalen 2009 1.jpg|thumb|[[2009 Superfinalen]], the first official match at the arena]] In June 2008, Stabæk announced they had signed an eleven-year sponsorship agreement with the [[telecommunications company]] [[Telenor]], where the latter would pay up to NOK 115 million for the sole naming rights for the arena, in addition to tickets and access to executive boxes.{{cite news |url=http://www.dagensit.no/bransje/article1431478.ece |title=Telenor betaler 115 millioner for stadion |work=Dagens IT |last=Riise |first=Kari Vartdal |date=24 June 2008 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=11 December 2009}} In March 2009, the retailing property was sold from [[Scandinavian Property Development]] to [[KLP Eiendom]].{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.no/eiendom/naering/article1625512.ece |title=Selger Fornebu-eiendommer |work=[[Dagens Næringsliv]] |date=6 March 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=11 December 2009}} The plans called for twenty to twenty-five football games, four to eight concerts, three to four large sports events and two other large events and conventions per year. Because of larger [[seating capacity]], an all-seating arrangement, higher attendance and VIP facilities, Stabæk is able to generate three times the matchday revenue from Telenor Arena as Nadderud.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/ikke-skriv-historien-om-arenaen-enna-1.5787282 |title=Ikke skriv historien om arenaen ennå |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Schultz |first=Einar |date=8 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yCoWHGZg?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/ikke-skriv-historien-om-arenaen-enna-1.5787282 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The stadium is plagued with traffic problems on matchdays, with large crews hired to create temporary barriers to direct the crowds. The bus stops closest to the venue are closed, and a large number of police officers have to direct the traffic. These are costs which have to be carried by the arena company, and contrasts to matches at the nearly twice as large Ullevaal, where no such measures are necessary. ===Football versus event controversy=== In October 2009, ten individuals bought the operation company of the club and signed a 40-year lease for the use of the arena for Stabæk's home matches, as well as the right to use the facility for certain other activities. This contract has a revenue of NOK 9 million per year.{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.no/forsiden/naringsliv/article1771727.ece |title=10 personer overtar Stabæk |last=Sparre |first=Martin Riber |work=[[Dagens Næringsliv]] |date=20 October 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=11 December 2009}} In 2009, [[Stabæk Holding]] had a deficit of NOK 66.1 million, while Stabæk Fotball lost NOK 23.6 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-kan-bli-kastet-ut-av-telenor-arena-1.5774178 |title=Stabæk kan bli kastet ut av Telenor Arena |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Morten Gisle |last2=Hagerup |first2=Mari |last3=Harnes |first3=Nils H. |last4=Bjørnstad |first4=Andreas |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBG8nJAJ?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-kan-bli-kastet-ut-av-telenor-arena-1.5774178 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} To keep the operating company running, Ulrichsen increased the company's share capital by NOK 73 million from late 2009 through late 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/nyheter/ulrichsen-vurderer-a-selge-seg-ut-1.5860917 |title=Ulrichsen vurderer å selge seg ut |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Morten Gisle |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBQQXLiy?url=http://www.budstikka.no/nyheter/ulrichsen-vurderer-a-selge-seg-ut-1.5860917 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} [[File:Telenor arena 0641.jpg|thumb|left|Training at the venue]] On 4 November 2010, Stabæk Holding stated that they were near a bankruptcy, and that they intended to throw out Stabæk as a tenant, remove the turf and instead use the venue exclusively for events. Chair [[Diderik Schnitler]] in Stabæk Holding stated that the business model was not sustainable. The football schedule was not made until early in the year, while in the event business, bookings were common one to two years in advance. It was therefore difficult to secure lucrative events, as large parts of the year had to be held in reserve in case the venue was needed for yet-to-be scheduled matches. The holding company stated that they might have to file for [[bankruptcy]]. Stabæk Fotball stated that they had a 40-year contract to use the venue.{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7366817 |title=Stabæk kan bli kastet ut av Telenor arena |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Jenssen |first=Grethe Kielland |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBG0uT5T?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7367402 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Stabæk's director of sports, [[Inge André Olsen]], stated that returning to Nadderud was not an option, as it had too little capacity and insufficient facilities.{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7367402 |title=– Uaktuelt å gå tilbake til Nadderud |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Haram |first=Ingrid Vestre |last2=Rismyhr |first2=Kim Peder |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBG0uT5T?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7367402 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Should Nadderud be used, it would have to be rebuilt, with new grandstands under roofs, VIP seating, a new parking house and new change room, which would cost NOK 100 million. Because of building permits, construction would take two to three years.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/utelukker-ikke-nadderud-retur-1.5774883 |title=Utelukker ikke Nadderud-retur |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Hagerup |first=Mari |last2=Johnsen |first2=Morten Gisle |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBJZX05b?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/utelukker-ikke-nadderud-retur-1.5774883 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Nadderud is also not approved to host games in the Premier League, so Stabæk would have to either play their games at [[Ullevaal Stadion]] in Oslo or [[Marienlyst Stadion]] in [[Drammen]]. Telenor stated that if Stabæk moved, they would have to re-negotiate the naming rights agreement for the arena, as the value of the contract was largely based on the naming exposure of Stabæk playing in the Premier League.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/telenor-vil-vurdere-sin-sponsoravtale-1.5775814 |title=Telenor vil vurdere sin sponsoravtale |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Harnes |first=Nils H. |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBJuNO3X?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/telenor-vil-vurdere-sin-sponsoravtale-1.5775814 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The company also stated that they had difficulty understanding the argumentation from the holding company, as there was no football being played October and March, but that the venue, which has the largest capacity for indoor concerts in the Oslo area, failed to attract large artists, such as [[Rihanna]], during the winter months.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/telenor-sjef-skuffet-over-arenadrift-1.5908351 |title=Telenor-sjef skuffet over arenadrift |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Olsson |first=Svein |date=22 December 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBL8Tlc6?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/telenor-sjef-skuffet-over-arenadrift-1.5908351 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 4 December, Stabæk Fotball stated that they were willing to move their training, [[Norwegian Football Cup]] and [[UEFA]] matches to either Nadderud or Ullevaal, as a compromise to free up more available time in the arena.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-villig-til-a-flytte-treninger-til-nadderud-1.5860934 |title=Stabæk villig til å flytte treninger til Nadderud |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Morten Gisle |last2=Hagerup |first2=Mari |last3=Harnes |first3=Nils H. |last4=Bjørnstad |first4=Andreas |date=4 November 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBG8nJAJ?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-kan-bli-kastet-ut-av-telenor-arena-1.5774178 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} This was rejected by NFF, who stated that the licensing rules required that a club's main arena be available for all league, cup and UEFA matches, and that a general exemption would not be given for the cup. In mid-December, Stabæk Fotball started the process of a judicial registration of the right to lease the venue, which was permitted according to the contract. This would grant Stabæk Fotball the right to continue to lease the venue even if the holding company went bankrupt. A [[preliminary injunction]] for this was granted by [[Asker and Bærum District Court]].{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/derfor-er-arenastriden-i-retten-1.5898362 |title=Derfor er arenastriden i retten |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Olsson |first=Svein |last2=Johnsen |first2=Morten Gisle |date=22 December 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yCrROILU?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/derfor-er-arenastriden-i-retten-1.5898362 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In a 16 December statement, three Stabæk Fotball officials said that they suspected that Ulrichen's plan all along was to convert the venue to a pure convention center, and that the use as a football venue was a decoy to get a free lot worth up to NOK 200 million plus grants worth NOK 50 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/sport/stab-k/stabek-slar-kraftig-tilbake-mot-arena-eier-1.5893323 |title=Stabæk slår kraftig tilbake mot Arena-eier |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Holmlund |first=Bjørnar |date=16 December 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBPqKqTj?url=http://www.budstikka.no/sport/stab-k/stabek-slar-kraftig-tilbake-mot-arena-eier-1.5893323 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The book value of the venue was NOK 303 million at the end of 2010, although a statement from the district court stated that the value of the venue was significantly lower than that. The bank [[DnB NOR]] held at the time a mortgage with security in the property worth NOK 260 million, while Ulrichsen through his investment company held a mortgage worth NOK 60.1 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/nyheter/tingretten-arenaen-er-verdilos-1.5917184 |title=Tingretten: Arenaen er verdiløs |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Morten Gisle |date=27 December 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yDNcR6jH?url=http://www.budstikka.no/nyheter/tingretten-arenaen-er-verdilos-1.5917184 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 7 January 2011, the parts announced that they had reached a compromise. Stabæk would remain at Telenor Arena for at least the [[2011 Norwegian Premier League|2011 season]]. In addition, the club held an option to take over the responsibility for events at the venue. Stabæk Fotball had until 30 June to accept the option, which would allow the club to remain at the venue on a permanent basis. This would require them to invest NOK 20 million in an event administration, which would increase event revenue, but at the same time move the risk from Stabæk Holding to Stabæk Fotball. If the club declined the option, they would not be allowed to play at the venue from the [[2012 Norwegian Premier League|2012 season]].{{cite web |url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-far-spille-pa-telenor-arena-1.5940071 |title=Stabæk får spille på Telenor Arena |work=[[Budstikka]] |last=Johnsen |first=Morten Gisle |date=7 January 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBPQBlcj?url=http://www.budstikka.no/konomi/stabek-far-spille-pa-telenor-arena-1.5940071 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7453992 |title=Stabæk blir på Telenor Arena i 2011 |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Jenssen |first=Grethe Kielland |last2=Rismyhr |first2=Kim Peder |date=7 January 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 April 2011 |archivedate=24 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBPVtCh7?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostlandssendingen/1.7453992 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 30 June, Stabæk announced that they would not fulfill the option to continue renting the stadium. The necessary NOK 35 million would entail a risk the club was not willing to take. The club stated that they hoped they could remain at the stadium by establishing a [[foundation (non-profit)|foundation]] which could purchase the venue form Ulrichsen. If this does not work out, the club will have to relocate from the 2012 season. The club is then considering relocating back to Nadderud, to Ullevaal or to Marienlyst. The club estimates that any relocation would result in the club losing half their revenue.{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.no/dnaktiv/article2172854.ece |title=Gir opp Telenor Arena |work=[[Dagens Næringsliv]] |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=30 June 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archivedate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Smxcgei?url=http://www.dn.no/dnaktiv/article2172854.ece |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Stabæk played its last match at Fornebu Arena on 20 November 2011, losing 1–2 against [[Haugesund FK|Haugesund]]. Subsequently, the pitch was removed, and Stabæk returned to Nadderud from the 2012 season.{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/sport/fotball/eliteserien/1.7883990 |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |title=–Vi skal til Nadderud |date=20 November 2011 |accessdate=20 November 2011 |archivedate=20 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63LTohQM7?url=http://www.nrk.no/sport/fotball/eliteserien/1.7883990 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The [[Norwegian Handball Federation]] announced in May 2013 that the arena would be used for a four-nation men's handball tournament, Bring Cup, in November. The federation stated that they would use the tournament to evaluate if the venue was suitable as a new national arena for handball.{{cite news |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/handball/-322217_1.snd |title=Telenor Arena blir storstue for håndball |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Sandvik |first=Trond |date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |archivedate=23 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LL7sv8zz?url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/handball/-322217_1.snd |deadurl=no |language=Norwegian |df=dmy-all }} The venue received mixed reviews. The tournament saw low attendance and Danish commentator Bent Nyegaard criticized the arena for being too large. The federation was happy with the arena, and stated that were planning on using it for finals in their bid for future World and European Handball Championships.{{cite news |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/handball/Dansk-handballprofil-slakter-Telenor-Arena-404453_1.snd |title=Dansk håndballprofil slakter Telenor Arena |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Sandvik |first=Trond |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |archivedate=23 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LL85Sn2m?url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/handball/Dansk-handballprofil-slakter-Telenor-Arena-404453_1.snd |deadurl=no |language=Norwegian |df=dmy-all }} Telenor Arena was part of the [[Oslo bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics]], in which it had been proposed to be used for [[short track speed skating at the Winter Olympics|short track speed skating]] and [[figure skating at the Olympic Games|figure skating]].{{cite news |url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/artikkel.php?artid=10101151 |title=Slik vil de ha Oslo-OL i 2022 |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |last=Byrkjedal |first=Mona |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |archivedate=23 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LL8VexNd?url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/artikkel.php?artid=10101151 |deadurl=no |language=Norwegian |df=dmy-all }} ==Facilities== [[File:Telenor Arena bench.jpg|thumb|A film crew at a match]] The venue is located at Fornebu, a peninsula in Bærum, located {{convert|10|km|sp=us}} from the city center of Oslo. The venue is owned and operated by Fornebu Arena AS, which is again owned by Stabæk Holding, which also owns Stabæk Fotball. Telenor, Norway's largest telecommunications company, holds the [[naming rights]] for the stadium. The venue has seating for 15,000 spectators for football, and 23,000 for concerts. This includes [[club seating]] for 1,200, 40 [[luxury boxes]] and a restaurant which can seat 800. The arena is entirely indoors, and has a height clearance of {{convert|23|m|sp=us}} to the beams and {{convert|33|m|sp=us}} to the roof. The floor surface is {{convert|120|by|82|m|sp=us}}, while the pitch is {{convert|105|by|60|m|sp=us}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.telenorarena.no/index.php?l1=78&pageID=37 |title=About Telenor Arena |publisher=Telenor Arena |accessdate=19 April 2011 |archivedate=19 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y3crE4Sj?url=http://www.telenorarena.no/en/index.php?l1=78&pageID=37 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The venue has a considerably lower heating cost than similar conventional halls because the warm air is stored in the building's concrete and steel elements, and using the inert energy created by the spectators.{{cite news |title=Elektrisk jubel|first=Sveinung |last=Jensen |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=27 February 2008 |page=29 |language=Norwegian}} The venue is the largest indoor stadium in Northern Europe. The retailing area of {{convert|2600|m2}} in the complex is owned by Arena Handel AS, a subsidiary of [[KLP Eiendom]]. The venue is owned and operated by a conglomerate of six companies all owned by Kjell Christian Ulrichsen. The mother company for the other companies is Stabæk Holding AS. Fornebu Arena AS is the actual owner of the real estate. Fornebu Event AS is responsible for renting out the venue for concerts, conventions and other non-sporting events. FA Leie AS partially leases and partially owns installed facilities in the venue. Sameiedrift Widerøeveien nr. 1 AS is the management company for the property as a whole. Arena Idrett AS hold the rental guarantee given to Fornebu Arena by the renters of the commercial properties and Sameiedrift Widerøeveien nr. 1. ==Transport== [[Ruter]] bus 31 is a high-frequency service which runs from the city center of Oslo via [[Lysaker Station]] to Fornebu. During regular schedule it stops just outside the stadium; however, on matchdays it stops further away because of traffic. Lysaker Station is served by both the [[Oslo Commuter Rail]] and selected intercity and regional trains. Dedicated football buses are operated by Ruter to Stabæk home games. There are 1,500 parking spaces immediately near the venue, although additional parking is available at IT Fornebu and at Lysaker, which are a seven- and fifteen-minute walk away, respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.telenorarena.no/en/index.php?l1=78&l2=96&pageID=30 |title=How to get here |publisher=Telenor Arena |accessdate=19 April 2011 |archivedate=19 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y3dr1SQJ?url=http://www.telenorarena.no/en/index.php?l1=78&l2=96&pageID=30 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The Fornebu Line is under planning, and would be built either as a [[light rail]] or a [[rapid transit]], which would allow rail transport from the city center of Oslo and Lysaker to the stadium.{{cite web |url=http://ruter.no/Global/dokumenter/dokumentvedlegg/fornebubane/Fornebu_sluttrapport_des2009.pdf |title=Fornebubanen Sluttrapport trasé og konsekvensutredning |publisher=[[Ruter]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=19 April 2011 |archivedate=19 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y3e40Kkc?url=http://ruter.no/Global/dokumenter/dokumentvedlegg/fornebubane/Fornebu_sluttrapport_des2009.pdf |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The arena often gets uncomfortably hot when the capacity is full and the organisers were criticized for the water priced at 44 NOK (approximately $7,2) for a cup with water. [[File:Slovenia at Eurovision 2010.jpg|thumb|[[Ansambel Roka Žlindre]] and [[Kalamari (band)|Kalamari]] represent [[Slovenia]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]] in the second semi final]] == Sports == Telenor Arena was the home ground for Stabæk Fotball, which plays in the [[Norwegian Premier League]]. The first match was a friendly against Sweden's [[IFK Göteborg]] on 24 January 2009. The official opening took place on 8 March, when it was host of [[Superfinalen 2009]], a pre-season match between Stabæk as league champions and [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]] as cup champions.{{cite news |url=http://www.tv2sporten.no/fotball/tippeligaen/se-norges-charity-shield-2600847.html |title=Se Norges Charity Shield |date=3 March 2009 |work=[[TV 2 (Norway)|TV2]] |accessdate=19 April 2011 |archivedate=19 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y3io3wpJ?url=http://www.tv2sporten.no/fotball/tippeligaen/se-norges-charity-shield-2600847.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | title=Stabæk viste mestertakter | work=[[Verdens Gang]] |url=http://www.vg.no/sport/fotball/norsk/artikkel.php?artid=551359 | accessdate=9 March 2009 | date=8 March 2009 | language=Norwegian}} Stabæk has played four UEFA tournament matches at Fornebu: against [[KF Tirana|Tirana]] and [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] during the qualification for the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League]], against [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] in the play-off for the [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League]], and against [[FC Dnepr Mogilev|Dnepr Mogilev]] in the qualification for the [[2010–11 UEFA Europa League]]. Stabæk's record attendance at Telenor Arena dates from 13 September 2009, when 13,402 people saw a league game against [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]]. The record in a UEFA game was 12,560, who saw the match against Copenhagen.{{cite web |url=http://www.stabak.no/menn/rekorder_menn/ |title=Rekorder |publisher=[[Stabæk IF]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=19 April 2011 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yCmwlZai?url=http://www.stabak.no/menn/rekorder_menn/ |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The following list shows the average, maximum and minimum attendance for Stabæk's home games in the Premier League. revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Tianhe Sports Centre Stadium
天河体育场 | image = [[File:Tianhe Stadium.jpg|350px]] | location = [[Tianhe District, Guangzhou|Tianhe District]], [[Guangzhou]], [[Guangdong]] | broke_ground = 4 July 1984[http://www.guangzhou.gov.cn/yearbook/20year/html/06224.htm 天河体育中心的设计和建设] | built = 1984–1987 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1987|8|30}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Guangzhou People's Government | operator = [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.]]
(on loan from Guangzhou Sports Bureau) | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao]] (2005, 2011–present) | dimensions = {{convert|105|by|68|m|yards}} | former_names = | coordinates = {{coord|23.140647|113.319328|type:landmark|display=inline}} | seating_capacity = 58,500 }} '''Tianhe Sports Centre Stadium''' ({{zh|s= 天河体育中心体育场}}), mostly known as '''Tianhe Stadium''' ({{zh|s= 天河体育场}}), is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Tianhe District]], [[Guangzhou]], [[China]]. It is currently used for [[Association football|football]] matches. == History == Construction of the stadium began on 4 July 1984 at the former site of Guangzhou Tianhe Airport. It was opened in 1987 for the 1987 [[National Games of China]].{{cite book |author=馮民牧，楊介林，廖汝忠，胡灼華 |title=《廣州市地名志》 |year=1989 |publisher=香港大道文化有限公司 |location=Hong Kong|isbn=7-5359-0296-0 |page=}} It hosted the final of the [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup|inaugural]] [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] in 1991. The stadium is hosting the home matches of local football team [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao]] since 2011. The stadium hosted the football finals of the [[2010 Asian Games]] and final match of the [[AFC Champions League]] twice, in [[2013 AFC Champions League Final|2013]] and [[2015 AFC Champions League Final|2015]]. [[File:Guangzhou_Evergrande_vs_FC_Seoul.jpg|left|250px|thumb|[[2013 AFC Champions League Final]] at Tianhe Stadium]] The operation right of Tianhe Stadium was loaned to Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C. from Guangzhou Sports Bureau for 20 years on 24 February 2016.[http://sports.sohu.com/20160225/n438428686.shtml 恒大富力租场20年 开启民营企业租体育场地模式] == Transport == The stadium is best reached by taking [[Guangzhou Metro]] [[Line 1, Guangzhou Metro|Line 1]] to [[Tianhe Sports Center Station]] (East Gate), [[Line 3, Guangzhou Metro|Line 3]] to [[Linhexi Station]] (North Gate) and Line 1 or 3 to [[Tiyu Xilu Station]] (West Gate and South Gate). == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://special.gznews.gov.cn/2010/node_831/tupian/img/2010/11/26/12907558587420_6.jpg Stadium picture] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title=[[FIFA Women's World Cup]]
Final Venue| before=None; inaugural event| after=[[Råsunda Stadium]]
[[Stockholm]]| years=[[FIFA Women's World Cup 1991|1991]] }} {{succession box | before = [[Jassim Bin Hamad Stadium]]
[[Doha]] | title = [[Football at the Asian Games|Asian Games Football tournament]]
Final Venue | years = [[Football at the 2010 Asian Games|2010]] | after = [[Incheon Munhak Stadium]]
[[Incheon]] }} {{S-end}} {{Guangzhou F.C.}} {{Guangzhou}} {{FIFA Women's World Cup Final stadiums}} {{1991 FIFA Women's World Cup stadiums}} {{Coord|23|8|26.33|N|113|19|9.58|E|type:landmark_scale:5000|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tianhe Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in China]] [[Category:FIFA Women's World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Venues of the 2010 Asian Games]] [[Category:Tianhe District]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Guangzhou]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1987]] [[Category:1987 establishments in China]]

Is the main governing body of all divisions of the [[Uzbekistan Super League|Uzbekistan Championship]], also [[Uzbek Cup|Uzbekistan Cup]] and [[Uzbekistan Super Cup]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://pfl.uz Official website] [[Category:Sports organisations of Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Football in Uzbekistan]] {{Uzbekistan-sport-stub}} {{Footy-org-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox Museum |name = World Figure Skating Museum & Hall of Fame |image = |caption = |coordinates = {{coord|38.79379|-104.84885|format=dms|display=inline, title|type:landmark_region:US-CO}} |established = |location = 20 First Street
[[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] |type = [[Hall of fame]] |publictransit= |website = [http://www.worldskatingmuseum.org www.worldskatingmuseum.org] }} [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-13104, Sonja Henie und Karl Schäfer.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=A woman and a man in figure skating blades stand on an outdoor ice rink posing for a shot. On the left, the woman has both hands in her waist, while the man has his right arm around her left arm.|[[Sonja Henie]] and [[Karl Schäfer]] were among the initial 20 inductees to the Hall of Fame in 1976.]] The '''World Figure Skating Hall of Fame''' serves as a repository for the sport of [[figure skating]]. The World Figure Skating [[Hall of Fame]] is where the greatest names in the history of the sport are honored. The World Figure Skating Museum and Hall of Fame is located in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]], [[Colorado]], United States. Skaters such as [[Dick Button]], [[Katarina Witt]], [[Midori Ito]], [[Sonja Henie]], [[Alexei Yagudin]] and [[Michelle Kwan]] have been honored in the Hall of Fame. ==Inductees== {|class=wikitable |- bgcolor="ffffff" ! [[Armenia women's national football team]] (2014–present) | embedded = | website = [http://www.footballacademy.am/en/ official website] }} Officially, the '''FFA Technical Center-Academy Stadium''' ({{lang-hy|ՀՖՖ Տեխնիկական-կենտրոն ակադեմիայի մարզադաշտ}}), commonly known as the '''Yerevan Football Academy Stadium''' or the '''Avan Academy Stadium''', is an all-seater [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]]. It is located in the northern [[Avan District]] of the city, within the Technical Center-Academy complex of the [[Football Federation of Armenia]]. The stadium is sometimes known as the Avan Football Academy Stadium. ==Overview== [[File:FFA academy stadium Yerevan, 08.08.2015.jpg|The main stand|thumb|left]] The 1,428-seated stadium[http://www.football365.am/wp/?p=115586 Football 365 article about the stadium] was officially opened on 29 April 2013 by the Mayor of Yerevan [[Taron Margaryan]].[http://www.armsport.am/hy/news/2013/04/29/%D5%8F%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B8%D5%B6-%D5%84%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A3%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A8-%D5%AF%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%A5%D6%81-%D4%B1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%A4%D5%A5%D5%B4%D5%AB%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB-%D5%B6%D5%B8%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%BC%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B5%D6%81-%D5%B4%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A6%D5%A1%D5%A4%D5%A1%D5%B7%D5%BF%D5%AB-%D5%A2%D5%A1%D6%81%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%B6-%D5%AF%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B4%D5%AB%D6%80-%D5%AA%D5%A1%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%A8/297265 Taron Margaryan at the Football Academy] However, the first official match in the stadium took place earlier on 13 April 2013, between [[FC Pyunik]] and [[FC Banants]] within the frames of the [[Armenian Premier League]]. The match ended up with a result of 4-0, in favour of Pyunik.[http://www.armsport.am/hy/photos/%D5%93%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%AB%D5%AF-%D4%B3%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%B1%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%9D-1-1/2497 Pyunik Vs Gandzasar at the Football Academy] The stadium has served as the home venue of the [[Armenian Premier League]] side [[FC Pyunik|Pyunik]] between 2013 and 2017. It is currently the home ground of the newly-founded [[FC Avan Academy]], playing at the [[Armenian First League]]. The stadium is part of the [[Yerevan Football Academy|Technical Center-Academy]] of the [[Football Federation of Armenia]] which was officially opened on 1 September 2010 by the [[UEFA]] president [[Michel Platini]]. The centre is home to the main football stadium, 9 football training pitches (8 natural and 1 artificial), 4 outdoor tennis courts, an indoor sports hall, indoor and outdoor swimming pools, fitness centre and a 4-star hotel with 49 guest rooms. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Armenian First League venues}} {{Football venues in Armenia}} [[Category:Football venues in Armenia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Yerevan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]]
